name: Eat Week 2: Red and Green (and Wait)

desc.sectionTitle: Experiment Focus: the Green, Red and Wait Effect.

sectionContent.content:
**Experiment Focus:  Explore how you feel when, for one week, you have Green and Red *First* any time you eat.**

You’ve practiced what “feeling full” is like. This week, with Green and Red, you’re exploring how particular food types affect feeling full, and also, how they affect feeling better – like having more energy, sleeping better, thinking more clearly.

**What are Greens and Reds?**

Green means Green Vegetables - Red means Protein: meat, fish, eggs - and if Vegan: mushrooms, legumes. 
 
**Why Green and Red?** The Value of Green and Red is that these are Reliable Foundations for everything your body needs in order to build, burn and recover better. When in doubt about what to have, anytime, anywhere, that’s all you need to check out: where is the green? Where is the red? and you’re covered. 

The other great thing is that you can use your senses especially vision, but also touch, to determine these foods.  

**Only Green and Reds? No, just R&G** *first*.

The focus this week is not to take away any particular foods, but to make sure, for at least this one week, you START every meal with Green and Red, and then WAIT – stand up, move around, pause, chat, whatever for a few minutes – and if you still feel the need for more food, have whatever else you’d have.  

**Does “Every time you eat” mean EVERY time you eat?**

Yes – this week, this experiment – it does mean EVERY time you eat.

If you like to have a cookie, a piece of toast, a can of pop – anything that has material in it that your gut needs to process, start with Red and Green and Wait – and if you still want that Other Thing, have it. Notice how you feel after the “wait” – are you feeling like you need food? Is it a craving instead? What would happen if you had a bit more Red or Green instead?

desc.sectionTitle: Knowledge is Power (to choose): Why Reds and Greens?

sectionContent.content:
**REDS are proteins - Meat, Legumes, Mushrooms, Fish, Poultry**

Usually, when you hear about protein and humans, it’s about muscle. While muscle is definitely built from protein, **Protein** isnt just about muscle; it’s about everything. Everything in our bodies, pretty much, is made up of proteins. Hair, skin, hormones. All our billions of cells use proteins in their nucleus to re-create themsleves from their DNA. Growth, repair, recovery, everything needs protein. In particular, there are a set of proteins (or really the building blocks of proteins, called *amino acids*) that we HAVE to consume, pretty much daily.

**Why protein daily: we don’t really have mechanisms to let us store protein.**

If you’ve ever said to yourself  “I’d like to lose some weight” we’re talking about, most of the time, wanting to burn off some fat.

In other words, we can store fat in our bodies over days, weeks, months – longer. We are designed to store that fat so we can have a constant fuel supply for our cells’ energy needs.

Just like our cells need protein as the raw materials to make us, those same cells also need fuel to run the cellular engines to *make* those proteins do stuff to keep us alive. It’s like having all the gear we may have at home like a vacume cleaner, a water heater, a TV, a fridge. Those things are great, but if the power goes out, there’s a black out, they’re useless. Nothing happens. Our fat acts like a battery – stored fuel that gets converted on demand to energy for running our cells. Sometimes we have more batteries than we can use – and that actually causes problems. But that’s another story.

**Unlike our ability to store fat for energy, we don’t have big reserves for those proteins.**

Because we only have very small “amino acid pools” in our bodies, that get used up over the day, we need to take in the proteins we need from our food, to replenish the pools for our body’s constant growth/repair/recover cycles.

PROTEIN SOURCES Meat, fish, poultry – creatures, in other words – are available to us as food as mostly protein. These meat sources also tend to have some of the fats we need for both fuel and other stuff too – our cells’ walls, for instance, are made up of mostly fats; transport systems used by the blood (cholesterol) to carry materials back and forth from the liver are made up of fats and proteins.

Dairy & Eggs also include protein – not as much relative to the other food components they have.  

Plants All plants have pretty much all the amino acids we need, but not in the amounts that we need to thrive. Consequently,  it takes more care to put together plants to make sure we get the protein components we need, regularly enough, to thrive. Vegans who have committed to learn how to put the time in to build up healthful meals from solely plant sources make this work for them every day – but it does take work.

FEELING FULL One of the cool things about protein is that when we get them from our food, those protein-rich foods take the longest to break down in our guts – so they tend to help us feel satisfied longer. So you can check that out, too this week in terms of both finding full and when you WAIT – after having the Reds and Greens – how long you feel satisfied.

**GREENS**

This week the plant focus is JUST on greens. Why, of all the possible plants, focus on just GREEN vegetables?

It’s like this: when in doubt go for greens first. Greens have more of the nutrients needed to thrive than any other plant cousin. Go for rich dark leafy greens or cruciferous (eg broccoli) and you’re covered.

Why?

Proteins as shown above are ESSENTIAL for you to survive and thrive.

For proteins to function – for the body to be able to make use of these amino acids for different processes whether fighting a cold or building muscle– there’s a need for other *nutrient components*  to be available that may not be present in various protein sources to be sufficient.

In other words, for proteins to combine to make stuff from hair to hormones, they need a variety of different ingredients either to facilitate or to be part of that material-making process.

You can think of all the different things in the world that use wheat grain: cakes, cookies, breads, beers. Flour is the foundation, but to deliver different flavours and textures, different additional materials are needed. Flour can’t do anything on its own. Flour with water and sugar can make desert; flour with water and salt completely different – but only one small ingredient has shifted.

Same with Greens. You’ve likely heard about **vitamins and minerals**. These components – and may other bits (called phytonutrients)  - are found in both plants and creatures.

For example, iron is an essential mineral for our blood to be able to process the air we breath – that is – without it, oxygen cannot be carried from the lungs to our cells. Without oxygen getting into our cells, they can’t produce energy for those necessary processes to keep us alive. We could breath in all the air in the world: no iron; no life. No kidding.

Iron is available in food from creatures. But a cup of cooked spinach has *way* more iron. In fact it’s got about 5 times as much iron as 3oz (100g) of steak. You have to go to chicken liver to beat a cup of spinach.

Spinach, kale, asparagus, brussel sprouts, broccoli, avacados (all greens) also are rich in a range of vitamins and minerals, not least the B vitamins that have a whole host of properties to help proteins build materials, and especially help in particular help with energy production.

These same veggies are also great sources of vitamin C, used for protecting our cells when they’re producing energy. Think of pollution associated with energy production – our cells do something similar when producing energy with “reactive oxygen species” – stuff that creates “rust” in the cells. When we eat foods that bring in vitamin C – like these greens – our bodies use those materials to help clean out the rust, and keep our cells functioning both better and longer.  
 
**NOT JUST REDS or GREENS**

What about all those other foods – like grains and different coloured vegetables.

We’re not saying at all ONLY green veg have these. What we’re saying is that Red and Green are your Go-To sources for getting all the *essential* nutrients you need to thrive. No matter where you are, if you go for red and green first, you know you’ll be in fine shape. They’re a solid foundation for your *feeling better* journey.

**Heuristic this week: Focus on the experience of Reds and Greens**

What to look for in greens: DARK green in colour; leafy, or cruciferous in texturegrown above ground. Yes avacados are fine as a SUPPLEMENT green choice this week, but not as a PRIMARY green.

What to look for in Reds: main nutrient – protein (https://feastgood.com/highest-protein-foods/). For **creature sources**, this is easy: protein is the highest nutrient -so any creature source from sea to land to air is grand. **In plants**, protein will most often be the second highest or even third hightest nutrient. Soy beans are one plant exception: protein is the highest nutrient in that plant (https://www.nutritiontable.com/nutritions/nutrient/?id=864). That just means more weight of a serving is protein than anything else.

desc.sectionTitle: Lab Set Up - Red and Green Prep SKILLS

sectionContent.content:
YOUR LAB SET UP: WHAT is Green? What is Red?  
Your lab set up this week includes:  

1. Greens and Reds – identifying Reds and Greens – for your groceries or when eating out 
2. Planning  and Prepping   Green and Reds for the types of meals you typically have to be ready to go for each time you eat throughout the week. 
3. Connecting with anyone – from family to friends - who might like to know what you’re trying – whether to invite them along, or to help with meal prep for the week, or for any kind of planning from shopping to eating out.  
  
Feel free to check out ideas for how to prep your lab for this experiment 

SECTIONS

[ What are Greens and Reds : Examples  ( **new page this is the inside lab set up page greens and red**)]  

What are Greens and Reds? In this experiment there are some simple heuristics for Greens and Reds. Greens are dark green colored leafy to curly vegetgables. Reds are proteins.  Some examples below: 

Greens are literally GREEN vegetables.  

[image greens]

In particular, these greens - you can eat pretty much as you’d like: dark leafy greens like spinach, collard greens, spring greens, brussel sprout tops, beet tops. There’s also the cruciferous greens like broccoli, kale, arugula, bok choy.  If you’re in doubt, or don’t want to fuss – just go for the darkest green veggies you see in the fresh (or frozen) sections of the market or grocery.  

Heroes in this space are Spinach and Broccoli. It’s easy to get frozen versions of each too, and they’re often less expensive and sometimes more nutritious.  There are many other greens and other cruciferous veg. We’re focusing here on the dark green ones.  

Reds  

[image reds]

A red is code for Protein. Protein is a particular type of nutrient that is essential for us to live. If you eat meat, you can think of your RED sources as: creatures. That is, anything with Eyes (or that would have had eyes). Typical reds are red meats like cow or venison. There’s also fish, chicken, eggs, other kinds of sea foods. Less typical reds are insects.  

For  plant based eaters like vegetarians, eggs are great sources of protein and other healthful nutrients. The ratios in dairy are not bad – but you need more of these sources than the equivalent weight in meat to get the equivalent amount of protein. That’s not bad; it’s just to be aware of when planning your eating times.  

For more exclusively plant-based eaters, great non-eyed sources of protein are legumes: soy, turtle beans, black beans, pinto beans, lentils. Here, instead of red as your main visual cue, think about small, usually dark in colour or practically white things. When they are dried – how they’re typically sold “raw” – their texture is also hard, sometimes smooth; sometimes more wrinkly.   

There’s also things like Setain that are refined from grains proteins, and Qunioa which is a grain that just happens to be higher in protein than most other grains.  

Nuts, nut butters, seeds and cheeses also supplement this space. By supplement, that while they have protein, that’s not their primary nutrient. Plant based eaters are better off – most of the time – looking for their red-equivalents to be as rich in that Protein as possible.  
 
OTHER REDS - FUNGI (mushrooms)  

[image shrooms]

  
Mushrooms have a reputation as being good protein sources. in 100g (3oz) only about 5-7g of protein will be there, pending type of mushroom. So they are more a complement among other sources than perhaps a primary.     

But thinking about complements is the way to think about plant proteins.   You get protein through plant combos:  EVERY whole plant in the green scene has protein. Veggies all have some protein, so it's pretty straight ahead to get protein and lots of other nutrients from plants. Those chickpeas, greens, seeds, 'shrooms - voila.    

Note 1:  Protein is found in MANY MANY food sources including grains and other vegetables – including the greens mentioned here. Many other vegetables have many great qualities too besides greens.  
For just this week, however, we’re focusing on upping the green/red experience as an experiment – a special test -  in order to assess how that kind of red/green experience helps you FEEL better.  

It make life simple: when in doubt about what to have – go red and green first. That’s it. 

NOTE 2: you’re not being asked to eat ONLY Green and Red – just for this week to START with green and red FIRST – and if still looking for FULL – have anything else you’re having, after that.  See how YOU feel – during the day, the next day; how you sleep – just see how you feel when you up your green and red. 
 

### [Meals and Snack ideas Greens and Reds:  Ideas and Strategies] 

Planning and Prepping Red and Green for the Week. 

To help think about the greens and reds you might want to fix during the week, let’s look at some Green and Red Meal ideas. These are not the only ideas, of course – your community may have even more strategies and experiences to share. 

If you eat breakfast,  for instance, and you usually have oatmeal (obviously beige, so not a green or a red), what will you have instead, to get your green and red in, first?  

Note, nothing wrong with oatmeal - but for this week - we're checking out concentrating Green and Red – as well as exploring how they can be used – and how they feel – when eaten across the whole day.   

Examples of Red and Green for breakfast include things like:  

- EGGS and SPINACH. Spinach can be a frozen spinach ball – pour hot water over it, and drain it – or after draining throw it into the skillet that cooked your egg  [you tube embed – julia child 45 second egg [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6qCi-buLGPM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6qCi-buLGPM)]  
- With a BLENDER - Have a protein shake with protein powder or yogurt or a raw egg and spinach or kale or greens powder or left over greens as a foundation.  For more ideas for morning “super shakes” our friends at Precision Nutrition have many suggestions [https://www.precisionnutrition.com/super-shake-creation](https://www.precisionnutrition.com/super-shake-creation)] 
 
 
- FISH – like sardines and some greens – if you had kale the night before and have left overs, it’s easy to reheat in a pan or with pouring some boiling water over them and straining.  Frozen spinach balls are also fantastic here – as they can be loosened up by putting in a cup of boiling water for a few minutes. 
- Dal PALAK - LENTIL STEW with SPINACH  - is great for making a bunch on Sunday that can last through the week. It can be made totally vegan, or with dairy, or with vegetable broth or chicken broth – it’s up to you. And if you make a whole lot – you can freeze in individual portion sizes, too, for fast access during the week for ANY meal of the day.   Here’s just ONE of a million recipes for this dish [https://lynnecurry.com/lentil-spinach-stew-recipe/] 

Snack Times Challenge: If you usually have an afternoon cookie with your cup of tea, what green and red will you have prior to that cookie? POSSIBILITY – you may be so satisfied by your breakfast or lunch that you forego a snack entirely. That’s ok, too. Else – raw broccoli and some walnuts can be an energy power hit.  

Examples of Lunches (in a Box) Especially if you have lunch at work, salads in reusable containers are fantastic.  

- SALADS! Mixed salad greens for the greens, or spinach alone or kale alone. For Reds: Chunks of TOFU (may be white but they rate as a plant based RED) with cooked lentils/beans, and a sprinkle of seeds like sunflower and seasame and pumpkin seeds, perhaps some walnuts. If you do dairy – a few crumbled bits of feta can be a lovely tang.  Other Reds – may be tinned fish – small tins can even wait to be opened onto the greens until lunch time.  

Examples of Dinners – the Family Challenge 

Especially if this is your main meal with your family, remember – neither you nor your family are restricted to ONLY red and green. It’s just for YOU, you’re experimenting this week to START with Red and Green before having anything else. 

We’ve found that having conversations in advance with your family about how to support your experiment AND not cause a lot of (or any) additional meal prep is a good idea.  

For instance, if you’re the only person having a green, frozen spinach balls, raw broccoli sticks – or fast steamed broccoli tips - offer an easy way to do an individual serving to meet your experiment – with very low prep time. Raw veg, as per week 1’s experiment, also takes a little more energy to chew.  

In other words: for family dinners you’re probably having a RED of some kind already. Now it’s just making sure at least YOU have that green available.  
  

[Shopping and Prepping for your own Greens and Reds] 

WHEN you SHOP – tag teaming? 

If you go in person, you can create a Sunday ritual – with family and friends if not just yourself: shop and chop – pick up your groceries for the week, and on Sundays prep meals for the rest of the week. You can cook mince in big batches, or stews, or broths on Sunday to have through the week – to freeze some or keep in the fridge (or in cold weather in tubs in the snow outside if that space is available).  

Buying in bulk – among friends can help with costs too, and perhaps you can support each other on this EAT journey together.  

IF you’re an online shopper with grocery delivery it can be even easier to outsource gathering groceries and delivering them to you.  

EASY GREENS AND REDS: When you shop Pick EASY Greens and Reds to Start. -   

1. Cans can be your friend to get going: canned fish can make sardines and greens in the morning easy. A can of black beans or chick peas – easy usually cheap protein either out of the can, or to make humus or veggie burgers. 
2. Eggs can be super fast to prepare: a scrambled egg or omlette takes less than half a minute to cook in a fry pan. Or – even faster - go all Rocky boxer training and have raw eggs in your morning Shake or Smoothie blended with greens. 
3. FROZEN – also excellent. Frozen veg are often flash frozen as soon as picked – same with fish – so that fresh goodness is locked inside. Frozen also lets you quickly grab enough green or red for individual servings, and pop the bag back in the freezer.  
4. A bag of salad, of spinach, any greens will stay fine in the fridge for a week.   
5. RAW or COOKED – Dual Use. VEG and PROTEIN that can be had raw or cooked gives you even more options. Spinach: raw or cooked; sashimi (raw fish) or cooked or smoked or steamed (makerel or sardines). Options options options! 

On the Go? TAKE your R&G WITH YOU.  

The easiest way to make this week work for you during the day if you’re at work is to Take Your Lab With You. If you're away from your own kitchen, having lunch worked out for the right green and red to pack up the day before is super handy, so you don't have to think about what to have.  

And to take it with you: REUSABLE CONTAINERS are a gift that keeps giving – well beyond this week’s experiment. Many types and sizes – just check they’re food grade plastic (polyproplene most of the time), and can be frozen, dishwasher safe.  

These containers are great as lunch boxes and also for storing individual portions.  
 
BASIC TOOLS: if you have a very basic kitchen – no worries. A cooking show on radio in Canada on the CBC once said: they only tools you REALLY need to prepare almost anything is (1) a good sharp Chef’s Knife (it’s about 8 inches long) (2) a wok. The wok is because it can double as a fry pan and a pot if needed.   Many many many of these items can be found at charity shops – especially if you’d like to supplement your kit with a lidded pot and perhaps a skillet for stove top cooking. A big pot is nice for slow cooking stews and broths. 

EATING OUT: HAVE IT YOUR WAY 

If you have to eat at a canteen or restaurant, an option is you can check out the menu in advance for your choice of greens and reds. Restaurants are there to serve you - so you can also ask for them to prepare something (like a hamburger wrapped in a lettuce leaf with a side green salad – perhaps instead of fries – for the same price).  

Some folks feel a little hesitant about asking for something not on the menu – and some restaurants may refuse – most will not. Don’t let that stop you. Try it once – if with friends – let them know they can support you in this – that you’re gonna give it a try – and you’ll see: it’s really fine, and eaasy and good places will always try to meet your wishes.  

AMOUNTS of green and red. Let’s reuse last week’s experiment guide for portion sizes: 
 
A typical single serving of a GREEN is what would fill your cupped hands. If it’s just greens however – you can pretty much have as much as you want – assuming a lot of dressing hasn’t been added   

A single serving of a Red - if it's a meat for instance - is the size (and thickness) of the palm of your hand. For adult guys, two palms of protein is a good starting place. For adult gals, it’s one palm to start. See how that goes.  Remember it’s green, red, wait. If after your “wait” you are just not feeling full, you might want to opt for more RED – that protein takes longer to digest so can help you feel full better, longer.  
  

### [Connecting with your Fellow Eaters]  

[images]

 For some folks, eating greens and reds with each meal is absolutely normal. For some folks, eating with colleagues at work, or especially if the main meal makers for the family at home, green and red can be a challenge.  

The one thing we hear the most about with this box is: the challenge of eating out, or making meals for families not used to green and red. 

For sure it can be challenging to introduce new practices around friends and family for eating – so here’s some tips both for yourself – and for having a conversation with colleagues. 

1. Green and Red is not the ONLY thing you can eat, it’s an ordering of important foods – to see what happens if having those first – how you feel both during the meal – where does full happen – and how do you feel during the day and week. 
2. You may let your family and friends know – even before this week – that you’re running an experiment – not a diet. It’s one week to try this out. They may wish to join you; you might have a conversation with your family about if they don’t want to join you – how they can support you – as surely they’d like you to feel as good as possible?  
3. If they don’t want to eat your greens or reds, and that’s ok – think about using single serving sizes of your greens and reds from frozen or canned sources so you can save what you don’t use. 
4. With kids you might ask them when shopping what Greens they can find in how many types? Dry beans, canned, cooked, even fresh? Explore how they feel, smell – which ones squish?  

What strategies have you used to follow this practice this week? By all means note them in your daily reflections part of your lab book for this experiment . 

[TIPS]

Many practice tips are sprinkled throughout the Lab Set Up Sections of this experiment. 

A few key ones repeated here include the main one being: Plan Ahead 

1. Meals – imagine 5 breakfasts, lunches and dinners. Are they all the same each day? different? What meals might be the challenges? 

 IF green and red is new to you for EVERY meal of the day, take a look at suggestions for how to use green and reds for each meal 

2. Sunday Ritual – Have your Greens and Reds gathered on Sunday to clean chop put into containers, or to cook up batches. 
3. Make it EASY – cook up things that are familiar to you for the reds and the greens.  
4. EXPLORE RAW and COOKED versions of Greens; EXPLORE fresh and frozen versions. 
5. Check out recipes with few ingredients and easy to try – eggs like scrambled are super fast; a can of sardines can be dumped onto a bed of defrosted, heated up spinach. If you wish, splash on some hot sauce.  

INVITATIONS 

1. If you’re concerned about people challenging your efforts, plan some time to share what you’re up to with them – that it’s for a limited time – and perhaps ask them to help come up with strategies to support you running your experiment.  

For the focus of the Experiment itself: 

1. How do you feel during the meal? Anything different from other times of eating? If you thought red and green breakfasts might be “weird” what were they? 
2. How do you feel during the week? How’s your energy? Patience? Sleep? 
 
 
Way to go for giving Green and Red a GO!

name: Eat Week 3: The Scent of Satisfaction

desc.sectionTitle: Experiment Focus: Exploring Sensible Snacks

sectionContent.content:
In the past two weeks, you’ve practiced Finding Full and starting with Greens and Reds – before adding anything else to help build, burn and recover better.  

Part of that build burn recover better is starting to balance the difference between being ready to eat food, and simply craving something. For example, if we’ve just had a good read and green meal at noon, and it’s only a couple hours later, but we have a craving, we’re not in a place where we physically *need* to eat something. After all, our guts are still processing that last meal. To our brain, though, that craving can feel very real. And it can distract us from focusing on anything else we need to do.

This week you're going to use your own inner wiring - in this case, your sense of smell - to help your brain bring in new information to crack the craving crises that lets the craving run you rather than the other way around. 

In this experiment you're going to create some Scent Snacks to use instead of taste snacks to help you feel how you feel better.

desc.sectionTitle: Lab Set up: Scent on Time Skills Building

sectionContent.content:
The  Experimental Practice for this week has TWO parts: 

1. **PART 1:** **SCHEDULE MEALS** For this week, EAT EACH MEAL AT THE SAME TIME EACH DAY of the experiment, for example: 7:30 for breakfast, noon for lunch, 6:30 for dinner. If you need to vary the time a bit on a particular day, try to make the shift as minimal as possible. 
2. **PART 2:** **USE SMELL SNACKS BETWEEN MEALS**.  Any time you feel like you want food but it’s not one of your planned meal times  - take a wiff of a pleasing but non-food smell. Cedar, coloured markers, incense, leather, flowers. Whatever works for you as a nice smell. 

We’ll talk about sources for these aromas in the Lab Set Up Section.

**Lab Set up for Sense-Able Snacks** 

1. Set up a schedule for your meals – however many you typically have. Find that time slot where you can commit to have that meal at that time – or as close to that time each day this week as possible.  

So if your first meal of the day is at 7:30am on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday, but Thursday it has to be 7:15 or 8:10– that’s fine.  The goal is to get those times booked in for you, and as close to the same time as you can.  

Remember:  you’re trying to get your body to connect better with your eating schedule, to work WITH your schedule. The more practices you give your body at that schedule, the better it will get. 
 

[image builder]

2. Gather Your Non-Food Smell Sources ahead of time. Before the experiment starts, pull together the scent sources you can have with you easily during the day. There are many non-food smells around us.  Examples include: 
 

- Cedar trees, 
-  lavender bushes,  
- flowers,  
- incense,  
- colored markers,  
- soap.  
- Essential oils 
- leather 
 
You don’t always need stuff in a bottle either: Outdoors? Nothing like running a hand along a lavender bush or cedar branch and inhaling the scent. Whatever you enjoy – and whatever you can have close by where you might be working or visiting or driving or doing whatever you’re doing.  

Test out a few smell sources before the experiment and see which you prefer and can have readily available.   See which ones may work better for you in different contexts, too. 
 
The next section shows your Lab Book for guiding your observations for this experiment.   

Just to cue up for your awareness, you’ll see you’re asked to: 

1. make some observations on your planned Eating session  
2. make some observations on your use of non-food smells between planned eatings. Within that observation, the number of times you used your non-food smells will also be helpful to note.

desc.sectionTitle: Daylight Dosing Focus

sectionContent.content:
## Experiment Focus Sleep wk 1: Getting Early Daylight

**Experiment Practice:** This week, the experiment practice is: to **get  outside for a 15-20 minute dose of daylight, as early in your day as possible**, and for each of the five days of the experiment.

**Experiment Skills**: These are your strategies to get that daylight dose as early in your day as possible. We’ll look at some options here in the Lab Prep section for this experiment.

**Experiment Knowledge** –

·      **Self-knowledge** – how do you feel during your day when you get that early dose? How does your energy, mood, relaxation, feel the next day on getting that dose?

·      **Bonus Science Knowledge** – what is early light doing for your body’s systems? - if you're interested in learning some of the science of light, check out section X

desc.sectionTitle: Lab Set Up for Daylight Dose

sectionContent.content:
## Lab Prep

**Your Lab this week has both Time and Space components:**

**1.     The TIME component is as early as you can in your day get your daylight**

**2.     The SPACE component is: outside – not in a window, but outside, get that unfiltered light.** 

- OUTSIDE is KEY: your light dose really does need to be with your head out of doors  - we look at options below 
- START OF YOUR DAY is also important. The closer you can get your outdoor light from the time you wake up, the better –

Why outside and why as soon as possible are explained in the Background section.

**Questions to help you Prep your Lab to run your experiment this week**

- What do you need to *plan in advance* to ensure you can get 15-20 minutes OUTSIDE as early in your morning as possible this week?
- Each morning of this five day experiment may be a little different pending your schedules – how will you work in your light each morning? 
- CONDITIONS: Sunglasses Off: Unless you have a particular condition requiring you to keep your eyes covered, the goal here is to keep your sunglasses off for these minutes in order to get that unfiltered daylight. Clouds - even if it’s cloudy, you’ll still get the full daylight dose from that light, so go right ahead. Shade – that’s fine too.
- OPTIONS for outside actions:
    - 
    - WALKING – it’s totally fine to do your daylight walking – it might be walking to your bus stop or taking the animals out for their early jaunt. Some of our participants say they have had voice meetings on their phones while walking to get their morning Daylight Dose in.
    - SITTING/STANDING – also fine to sit, or stand – meditate with your eyes open; have a coffee.
    - EXERCISE – this too is completely fine if the morning is your time to do your moves – and your environment allows. Go for it.

**** 

## Some other Considerations, pending the Season

- WEATHER What’s your weather plan? even it it's chilly or wet, what will let you get outside for that daylight dose?       
- SEASONAL LIGHT If it's that time of year when it's dark out when you get up - it's still all about getting that bolus of outdoor daylight as soon as you can once the sun is up, and in a way that you won't need to wear sunglasses.   
- FEEL BETTER TOGETHER: SHARING - is there someone you might invite to share any of these light dose occasions with you? Even if you're not together physically, you might agree to virtually do that morning walk, or coffee - just for you.   
- Some of our participants say they have had voice meetings on their phones while walking to get their morning Daylight Dose in.
 
**Any Way You Can** As you can see , the main thing, the PRINCIPLE of interest is – to get that early morning light, outdoors, for 15-20 minutes as early as you can.

**BONUS:** After that morning dose, getting additional doses of daylight outside throughout the day – also very helpful. If you can step outside for a bit at noon over lunch or for a walking meeting or whatever – see how that feels too.

desc.sectionTitle: Darkness Dosing - Experiment Focus

sectionContent.content:
This week, the exploration is around the effect of darkness at the evening end of our day on the quality of our sleep, on our recovering - better. 

[image] 

While getting light as soon as possible after rising is critical for syncing up our inner clocks so we get better sleep quality, so too is getting darkness before sleep, and then keeping things dark during the night.  

## **EXPERIMENTAL FOCUS of DARK DOSING:**  
**The experience of Time in End of Day Darkness**
 
**Experiment PRACTICE: Going Dark**

-              towards evening, to have **a few hours of *as dark as possible*** – before sleep; keeping things dark during sleep time, til wake.  

**EXPERIMENT SKILLS:**

-              How will you be able to create a few hours of darkness in your enviornment(s) before sleep – in particular if this is the summer and the sun is staying up quite long?

-              For this week, how will you make this darkening ok for your family/room mates/anyone else in your environments?

**Experiment KNOWLEDGE**:

1.        Self-Knowledge **How does darkness help affect your sleep? Affect how you feel*?*** How does exploring a darkness practice before bed and through the night affect not only your sleep quality, but how you feel both before sleep, and on waking? Are you more relaxed before sleep? More calm on waking, quietly ready to start the day? Something else? What surprises you?

2.        Bonus Body knowledge: What is the pre-sleep darkness dose doing, physically?

desc.sectionTitle: Darkness Dosing: Lab Set up

sectionContent.content:
The set up for this week’s lab is to figure out a way to maintain very low to no artificial light for two or so before you go to sleep, and to keep things as dark as possible as you sleep. 

The rest of this section explores some options to  

1.        Explore adapting your eyes to darkness 
2.        Types of lighting to use  
3.        Options during sleep 
4.        Working with the folks you live with 
 
[IMAGE]

**Night Vision: Time for Accommodation** Any time even before this experiment starts – give yourself a real darkness soak so that you KNOW what darkness is, and how your eyes adapt to it.  

- Here's how:
- Set a timer for 15 minutes
- Let yourself sit in a dark room – no lights 
- See what features starts to emerge from the darkness.  

## You may already be familiar with this effect if you get up in the middle of the night and there’s no lights on, but you can see shapes, edges, slight luminosity. 
 
Daily Darkness Dosing Practice Options

**Darkness Lighting at the Ready in hours before sleep–** If your room lights do not have dimmers – what might you use to keep the lighting during this experiment as low as possible?  It may mean having some alternative dark lighting tools
 

[images of lighting options]
 
Shown here are some options: candles, like tealights, can be purchased in packs, and last for several hours. Small rechargeable LED lights also options – the one shown shakes to be turned on and off – and can sit just about anywhere. 

**Computer Screens /Phones - –** Just turn down the light level – at night – when it is dark from the time of year – or even in the spring as light stays out later – it’s quite interesting to see how low a computer screen can be set and still be legible – especially when your eyes are light adapted.  

 **The Process of Darkening** There’s some work to suggest that these device screens are not THAT disruptive to sleep onset.  That’s great to know – for this week’s experiment to be as clear as possible – you can also consider the various challenges for getting to more darkness more of the time before sleep.  

**Darkness in Sleep – Room/Eyes Prep –** How dark is your room at night? Does light creep in? Perhaps earlier than you wake up? If you cannot get your room blacked out to enjoy that cover during the night, for this week, consider a sleep mask – anything to cover your eyes as you sleep – just for this week. And of course, if you like it, keep it.  
 
**Conversations** If you live with other folks – what conversations do you need to have to support your explorations of darkness? How might you build these spaces and practices together – before the experiment starts?

desc.sectionTitle: Darkness Dosing: Background

sectionContent.content:
There are two key parts to working with darkness deliberately in the hours before sleep.

**One. part** is that humans, in coming down from the trees and moving from loan creatures of the night to social creatures of the day, have evolved to sync up with the light and dark cycles and seasons of the planet.  Physiologically, genetically,  these phases are used to support activity during the light, and to use the darkness for the recovery, repair and consolodation of sleep.

**Dark as opposed to Artificial Light**  - When artificial light is used to extend the length of the day, that light disrupts those natural rhythms the early daylight helps sync up your body’s complex systems that are in turn sunk up with the planet’s night/day (dark/light) phases.

That light fights with our circadian physiology that seeks to start to wind down and go into our recovery (sleep) state. By working with rhythms the dark end of the day, we help support these natural processes that help us shift gears from our waking active selves to our sleeping, recovery and repairing selves.  

These shifts include hormones for relaxing, starting into sleep,   – and darkness is a cue that supports those processes towards rest and sleep itself.

We perceive the shift to darkness by a change in light. The nerves in our eyes detect these light shifts – this is the case even in blindness.

**Night Vision**   A **second part** of working with darkness is to allow our visual system – the system that takes in data from the eyes to process it into meaninful information - to get some practice too.  That practice  - explored in the 15min darkness dunk – allows a very perceivable shift in how we see.

If we go from a light bright room into a darker room – the room initially appears black wihout discernable colour or shape. Within minutes however our eyes adjust to make use of even the tiniest amounts of light to begin to perceive shape, though not colour to anywhere near the definition in daylight.  In darkness, the rods – the photo receptive nerves in our eyes for low light become more active. If a light is suddenly turned on when our eyes are dark adjusted we can experience brief discomfort from the sudden overdose of light to our sensitized low light senors.

As with any part of the human system, that capacity to work with darkness is a use it or lose it stremgth and a skill. Using the time in darkness before sleep to wind down can be a practice to see what is apparent in the darkness.

**Why Night Vision**

While we are wired to sleep in the darkness, we have scotopic or night vision capabilities – not as precise as our daylight vision, but still good at detecting movement, shape and, with practice, getting better at *seeing in the dark*. Why might we have evolved that skill if we are daylight movers and night sleepers? Is it just a leftover feature from millions of years of evolution? Or something that continued – and continues – to be a benefit for human thriving?
